sentence: Example trimming:. I want to trim my PE dataset like this:. - trim quality at 3' end. - trim poly G and poly A at 3' end. - finally trim 10 bases from both ends 5' and 3' of read pair. .. order is important. Theoretically I could do this in just one single call of `fastp`. In practice I need to know the order of execution of the individual steps. Alternatively I would need to run trimming in two or more separate processes like this to force a certain order of execution:. `fastp <quality/polyX params> | fastp <cut bases at all ends params>` or something similiar. ut that would probably reduce speed ... . Any thoughts on that? thanks :-)
author: OpenGene

sentence: Example trimming:. I want to trim my PE dataset like this:. - trim quality at 3' end. - trim poly G and poly A at 3' end. - finally trim 10 bases from both ends 5' and 3' of read pair. .. order is important. Theoretically I could do this in just one single call of `fastp`. In practice I need to know the order of execution of the individual steps. Alternatively I would need to run trimming in two or more separate processes like this to force a certain order of execution:. `fastp <quality/polyX params> | fastp <cut bases at all ends params>` or something similiar. ut that would probably reduce speed ... . Any thoughts on that? thanks :-)
author: OpenGene

sentence: OK, it's described in the README and - due to the hardcoded order - forces my workflow to be split in two separate fastp jobs .. not optimal :-(
author: OpenGene

sentence: OK, it's described in the README and - due to the hardcoded order - forces my workflow to be split in two separate fastp jobs .. not optimal :-(

sentence: Actually I use the STACKS pipeline to analyse RADseq data, from the raw fastq files to the final vcf file. One of the first steps is to clean (remove adaptor contamination and low quality reads) and demultiplex the reads into samples. The library is usually made by ligating unique barcode to digested DNA or combination of barcode + index. So by giving the barcode exact sequence (or barcode + index sequences), the reads are split into different samples before going through the following steps. This seems to be all in one tool. So I wonder if it would be possible to do this demultiplexing step (as in the Stacks pipeline) also within it, by giving the sequences of barcodes (usually 5 to 12 bp or even a bit longer).
author: OpenGene

sentence: The bcl2fastq Illumina program would demultiplex samples based on universal index short sequences, but the obtained demultiplexed "samples" are often a mix or samples that would be separated based on barcodes at the beginning of the sequences (read1 for example, between the adaptor and the start of actual DNA sequence).
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: Understood. You mean that multiple samples share the same `sample index`, and can only be demultiplexed using the barcode from the inserted DNA (read1 / read2)
author: OpenGene

sentence: Yes, sure. Here are two examples. The file barcode6.txt contain the simplest case. A barcode and the corresponding sample name on the same line (tab separated). The second file barcodesPool1.txt contains a combinatorial case, a sample corresponding to a combination of barcode and an index. In the case of the second file, often, the files were already demultiplexed with the Illumina software and the index tags are added to the IDs of the sequences (so barcode is inline and index is in the ID name). It can also happen that the Illumina first demultiplexing is not done, in which case the second file is even more important since you will have all combinations of barcodes + indices. Please note that in some cases, the barcodes can be of variable lengths within the same big file. [barcode6.txt](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/files/1941573/barcode6.txt). [barcodesPool1.txt](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/files/1941577/barcodesPool1.txt).
author: OpenGene

It can also happen that the Illumina first demultiplexing is not done, in which case the second file is even more important since you will have all combinations of barcodes + indices. Please note that in some cases, the barcodes can be of variable lengths within the same big file. [barcode6.txt](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/files/1941573/barcode6.txt). [barcodesPool1.txt](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/files/1941577/barcodesPool1.txt).

sentence: Just a guess -- is this due to running the zlib compression in the main thread? forking a process or adding a thread dedicated to compression may help resolve this issue. also, at the risk of piling too many feature requests in one ticket, there should be an option to output with no compression at all, so fastq data can be piped around directly (e.g. to another entirely different / custom compression tool)
author: OpenGene

sentence: @eqhmcow if the output file name has no .gz extension, it will not be compressed. So file names like "out.fastq" make plain text output. Currently the zlib compression of both R1 and R2 are in same thread, and I gonna to separate them to accelerate the compression. Thank all of you.
author: OpenGene

sentence: @eqhmcow if the output file name has no .gz extension, it will not be compressed. So file names like "out.fastq" make plain text output. Currently the zlib compression of both R1 and R2 are in same thread, and I gonna to separate them to accelerate the compression. Thank all of you.
author: OpenGene

sentence: @jasper1918 Currently you can output uncompressed data, and then compress them by pgzip once the output is done. This will eat more disk space, but may be a bit faster.
author: OpenGene

sentence: @jasper1918 Currently you can output uncompressed data, and then compress them by pgzip once the output is done. This will eat more disk space, but may be a bit faster.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Now, fastp is even faster. The gz writers are moved to individual threads. `-z 4` is default by now, which is a balance of speed and compression rate. `-z 6` is still not recommended since gzip compression is too slow
author: OpenGene

sentence: Now, fastp is even faster. The gz writers are moved to individual threads. `-z 4` is default by now, which is a balance of speed and compression rate. `-z 6` is still not recommended since gzip compression is too slow
author: OpenGene

sentence: Hello All,. An open soure parallel gzip tools from zlib called "pigz", this tools use multithreads to commpress the file,in order to reduce disk usage ,u can try write no compressed xxx.fq file to a xxx.fifo file then compress it to .gz file with using "pigz". find more information ----->[http://zlib.net/pigz/](http://zlib.net/pigz/) . Thx!

sentence: Currently fastp can handle multiple adapters for paired-end data, automatically. You don't have to input the adapter sequences. But for SE data, only one adapter is supported.

sentence: Well, we only have one real adapter. But depending on the protocol, the sequenced reads contain sometimes at the 3'-end also other things like the template switching oligo or the Nextera Transposase. These are artifacts of the library construction.

sentence: Just saw this. I think it would be useful to include multiple adapter feature. My colleagues are stick with Trimmomatic simply because of this. . Stephen Turner just added a collection of adapters in [this repo](https://github.com/stephenturner/adapters). May be worth implementing in the new version of fastp.

sentence: Hi all, this feature is implemented in fastp v0.19.10. See the introduction below:. ---. You can specify `--adapter_fasta` to give a FASTA file to tell `fastp` to trim multiple adapters in this FASTA file. Here is a sample of such adapter FASTA file:. ```. >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 1. AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA. >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. >polyA. AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA. ```. The adapter sequence in this file should be at least 6bp long, otherwise it will be skipped. And you can give whatever you want to trim, rather than regular sequencing adapters (i.e. polyA). `fastp` first trims the auto-detected adapter or the adapter sequences given by `--adapter_sequence | --adapter_sequence_r2`, then trims the adapters given by `--adapter_fasta` one by one.
author: OpenGene

AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA. ```. The adapter sequence in this file should be at least 6bp long, otherwise it will be skipped. And you can give whatever you want to trim, rather than regular sequencing adapters (i.e. polyA). `fastp` first trims the auto-detected adapter or the adapter sequences given by `--adapter_sequence | --adapter_sequence_r2`, then trims the adapters given by `--adapter_fasta` one by one.

sentence: with --adapter_sequence, fastp not only trim the provided adapter sequence, but the following sequence as well. . One example:. given adapter sequence: ATTGGAGTCCT. before fastp:. AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG**ATTGGAGTCCT**CCCCTTCCTCTTTTCTTTTAATAGAATTGCTTTAAGTATTACATGAGTGATGATATTAGCCGTGACTCAGATGGAATGGATGAACAATGTAGGTAGGT. after fastp:. AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG. Is this a bug? Thanks.

sentence: > with --adapter_sequence, fastp not only trim the provided adapter sequence, but the following sequence as well. > . > One example:. > given adapter sequence: ATTGGAGTCCT. > before fastp:. > AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG**ATTGGAGTCCT**CCCCTTCCTCTTTTCTTTTAATAGAATTGCTTTAAGTATTACATGAGTGATGATATTAGCCGTGACTCAGATGGAATGGATGAACAATGTAGGTAGGT. > after fastp:. > AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG. > . > Is this a bug? Thanks. It is as expected. You should never specify a short and repetitive sequence as adapter.
author: OpenGene

sentence: > with --adapter_sequence, fastp not only trim the provided adapter sequence, but the following sequence as well. > . > One example:. > given adapter sequence: ATTGGAGTCCT. > before fastp:. > AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG**ATTGGAGTCCT**CCCCTTCCTCTTTTCTTTTAATAGAATTGCTTTAAGTATTACATGAGTGATGATATTAGCCGTGACTCAGATGGAATGGATGAACAATGTAGGTAGGT. > after fastp:. > AATGGAGTCCAGAGACAGGTTCTAGACTAG. > . > Is this a bug? Thanks. It is as expected. You should never specify a short and repetitive sequence as adapter.

sentence: On our HPC cluster, the default Makefile did not work as it could not find include files and library files for zlib.

sentence: ```. Create destination parent directory in case it does not exist. when installing the compiled binary with "make install". ```. I removed `-D` option change since it's not supported on Mac OS X.

author: OpenGene

sentence: > I removed `-D` option change since it's not supported on Mac OS X. I didn't consider that fastp could be run on Mac OS X as I never copy FASTQ files to my own laptop. For Mac OX X and BSD, the flag would be `-d` instead of `-D`. https://linux.die.net/man/1/install. > -d, --directory. > treat all arguments as directory names; create all components of the specified directories . > **-D**. > create all leading components of DEST except the last, then copy SOURCE to DEST . https://developer.apple.com/legacy/library/documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man1/install.1.html. > **-d** Create directories. Missing parent directories are created as required. https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=install. > -D	destdir. > 	 Specify the DESTDIR (top of the file hierarchy) that the items. > 	 are installed in to. If -M metalog is in use, a leading string. > 	 of	``destdir'' will be removed from the file names	logged to the. > 	 metalog. This option does	not affect where the actual files are. > 	 installed. > . > **-d**	 Create directories. Missing parent directories are created as. > 	 required. To workaround this different flags, `mkdir -p` can be used to create missing parent directories if necessary. ```make. install:. mkdir -p $(BINDIR). 	install $(TARGET) $(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). @echo "Installed.". ```
author: OpenGene

To workaround this different flags, `mkdir -p` can be used to create missing parent directories if necessary. ```make. install:. mkdir -p $(BINDIR). 	install $(TARGET) $(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). @echo "Installed.". ```

sentence: @ChristopherLeach123 . In case someone ever needs this, here is a simple Python script I used for to run fastp one by one. Simply change the input and output directory path in the script and run the script:. ```import os. import subprocess. # Set input and output dirs. input_dir = "INPUT/DIRECTORY". output_dir = "OUTPUT/DIRECTORY". os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True). # Loop over all input files. for filename in os.listdir(input_dir):. if "_R1_" in filename and filename.endswith(".fastq"):. in1 = os.path.join(input_dir, filename). out1 = os.path.join(output_dir, filename). in2 = in1.replace("_R1_", "_R2_"). out2 = out1.replace("_R1_", "_R2_"). # Now run fastp command. if os.path.exists(in2):. command = f"fastp --in1 {in1} --out1 {out1} --in2 {in2} --out2 {out2} -w 10". print(f"Running command: {command}"). subprocess.run(command, shell=True). else:. print(f"Matching _R2_ file not found for {in1}"). else:. print(f"{filename} does not include '_R1_' or is not a fastq file")```
author: OpenGene

sentence: @ChristopherLeach123 . In case someone ever needs this, here is a simple Python script I used for to run fastp one by one. Simply change the input and output directory path in the script and run the script:. ```import os. import subprocess. # Set input and output dirs. input_dir = "INPUT/DIRECTORY". output_dir = "OUTPUT/DIRECTORY". os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True). # Loop over all input files. for filename in os.listdir(input_dir):. if "_R1_" in filename and filename.endswith(".fastq"):. in1 = os.path.join(input_dir, filename). out1 = os.path.join(output_dir, filename). in2 = in1.replace("_R1_", "_R2_"). out2 = out1.replace("_R1_", "_R2_"). # Now run fastp command. if os.path.exists(in2):. command = f"fastp --in1 {in1} --out1 {out1} --in2 {in2} --out2 {out2} -w 10". print(f"Running command: {command}"). subprocess.run(command, shell=True). else:. print(f"Matching _R2_ file not found for {in1}"). else:. print(f"{filename} does not include '_R1_' or is not a fastq file")```
author: OpenGene

sentence: How did you installed fastp previously? fastp is not integrated in apt-get server. But you can upgrade fastp by following methods:. 1. download the latest code, make and make install. 2. download the latest binary from http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp, `chmod a+x ./fastp`, find the old fastp path by `which fastp`, then copy the new fastp to replace the old one.
author: OpenGene

sentence: The difference of fastp and AfterQC was caused by:. * fastp counts a pair of reads as 2 reads, while AfterQC counts a pair of reads as 1 read. * fastp use 1000 as 1K, while AfterQC use 1024 as 1K. I will update AfterQC to keep them consistent. BTW, AfterQC will not be continued for development since fastp is far far better. So please use fastp other than AfterQC, for any applications.
author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp requires a little RAM. 2G is more than enough. BTW, usually 2 or 3 cpus are enough. fastp is I/O limited since it runs too fast than read/write.

sentence: With the exception of NGSUtils, I couldn't find any other tools or scripts to split reads within a FASTQ file into smaller reads (with or without overlap). So it's probably not very commonly needed, but this might change as long-read sequencing becomes more popular. In my case, I'm trying to accurate determine gene copy number in a genome via relative Nanopore read coverage, but my target gene has multiple repeats on a scaffold that is about the same size as the median read length of my Nanopore reads. I expect to get more accurate results if I can chop my reads up in shorter fragments before aligning them to my reference genome, but so far I haven't found an existing tool to do that.
author: OpenGene

So it's probably not very commonly needed, but this might change as long-read sequencing becomes more popular. In my case, I'm trying to accurate determine gene copy number in a genome via relative Nanopore read coverage, but my target gene has multiple repeats on a scaffold that is about the same size as the median read length of my Nanopore reads. I expect to get more accurate results if I can chop my reads up in shorter fragments before aligning them to my reference genome, but so far I haven't found an existing tool to do that.
author: OpenGene

sentence: @rmzelle This request doesn't sound like something that should be a feature of a trimming tool. It seems to be a specialized request that may require programming something from the ground up.

sentence: I know its a recent version of `fastp` as I build the dock about 2 weeks ago. I have notice it has issue with both WGS and WES data. . What will happen is a run will hang indefinitely, or until it's killed (now set to 2 hours). But if a job is killed and restarted, it will often run through quickly. It seems like it a strange behavior.

sentence: I notice this too. I used fastp 0.18.1 installed via pip. 191 jobs submitted to HPC through SLURM. 110 jobs finished in 5min. However, rest of jobs hangs there for the entire node time (I tried 1h and 3h). The trimmed files seem already generated. But the reports never generate and jobs keep going. . Any ideas? Thanks!

sentence: Hi all,. I revised the threading model of fastp. Please help to update to the latest v0.19.1, test it and update here. I hope this time it will not hang. If it still hangs, please also paste the log here. Thank you very much.

sentence: We are still having a similar issue on 0.23.1. Should we upgrade to 0.23.2 instead?
author: OpenGene

sentence: We are still having a similar issue on 0.23.1. Should we upgrade to 0.23.2 instead?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Hi, I still have the same problem in version 0.23.2. I think I figured how to reproduce this behavior (though I don't know why this is the case). When running fastp in a container, the command will run if it is run by itself. However, when using Cromwell, the command is wrapped as. ```bash. set -x. (. fastp command... ). ```. and then it will fail. Basically, when wrapping the command in `set -x ()`, fastp will hang. Interestingly, I have this problem only with ChIP-seq fastq files. I can run other analyses (RNA-seq, DNA-seq) even wrapped in `set -x ()` with no issues. Is there a workaround for this version? Thanks
author: OpenGene

I can run other analyses (RNA-seq, DNA-seq) even wrapped in `set -x ()` with no issues. Is there a workaround for this version? Thanks
author: OpenGene

sentence: @royfrancis 's idea of an prinseq alike approach would be very interesting! Given a normal distribution of read GC contents one could throw away +/- 3 standard deviations below/above the global mean GC. Another very simple approach would be to throw away all reads which have an 'insanely' low/high GC... something like < 15 % or > 85 %. Might be interesting to have a systematic view on let's say all RefSeq genomes to get a proper guideline....
author: OpenGene

sentence: Computing a GC cut-off is going to be tricky as it will depend heavily on the dataset (organism, tissue, highly expressed transcripts, mitochondrial reads etc). It might be easier to just leave it to the user to set a cut-off.

sentence: This is very risky for bacteria which often contain mobile genetic elements with GC quite different to the rest of the chromosome. Some key genes like the shiga-toxins in _E.coli_ are extreme GC (>85%) in the middle of the gene and often have poor sequencing coverage already.
author: OpenGene

sentence: hmm... ok then it's certainly a bad idea.. I once implemented an after-assembly contig filter including this criteria but this was meant for contigs which is a different story. Still, it would be interesting to have a systematic view on GC min/max values over a huge range of bacterial genomes with a sliding window, .e.g. 150 nt. I'll put it on my list :-)
author: OpenGene

sentence: Implemented. * If you want to trim the reads to maximum length, you can specify `-b, --max_len1` for read1, and `-B, --max_len2` for read2. If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```
author: OpenGene

If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```
author: OpenGene

sentence: Implemented. * If you want to trim the reads to maximum length, you can specify `-b, --max_len1` for read1, and `-B, --max_len2` for read2. If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```

sentence: Here's an assembly of some public Drosophila data: https://github.com/sjackman/abyss-drosophila-melanogaster. Here are the mate-pair reads: https://trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Traces/sra/?run=SRR3663860. Here's the command that I used to trim the mate pair reads: https://github.com/sjackman/abyss-drosophila-melanogaster/blob/52cfc55bbde0f435c48ca2f604180b233739aba5/Makefile#L149. Are you familiar with Nextera mate-pair reads? When the adapter occurs in the middle of a read, you effectively end up with three reads, which create a forward-reverse (paired-end-like) read pair and a reverse-forward (mate-pair-like) read pair. My preference is to keep the reverse-forward read pair and discard the forward-reverse read pair. Here's a related discussion with the author of NxTrim: https://github.com/sequencing/NxTrim/issues/50
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: Implemented. * If you want to trim the reads to maximum length, you can specify `-b, --max_len1` for read1, and `-B, --max_len2` for read2. If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```
author: OpenGene

sentence: Implemented. * If you want to trim the reads to maximum length, you can specify `-b, --max_len1` for read1, and `-B, --max_len2` for read2. If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```

sentence: Implemented. * If you want to trim the reads to maximum length, you can specify `-b, --max_len1` for read1, and `-B, --max_len2` for read2. If `--max_len1` is specified but `--max_len2` is not, `--max_len2` will be same as `--max_len1`. For example, if `--max_len1` is specified and read1 is longer than `--max_len1`, `fastp` will trim read1 at its tail to make it as long as `--max_len1`. Please note that the trimming for `--max_len` limitation will be applied at the last step. Following are fastp's processing steps that may orderly affect the read lengthes:. ```. 1, UMI preprocessing (--umi). 2, global trimming at front (--trim_front). 3, global trimming at tail (--trim_tail). 4, quality pruning at 5' (--cut_by_quality5). 5, quality pruning at 3' (--cut_by_quality3). 6, trim polyG (--trim_poly_g, enabled by default for NovaSeq/NextSeq data). 7, trim polyX (--trim_poly_x). 8, trim adapter by overlap analysis (enabled by default for PE data). 9, trim adapter by adapter sequence (--adapter_sequence, --adapter_sequence_r2. For PE data, this step is skipped if last step succeeded). 10, trim to max length (---max_len). ```
author: OpenGene

sentence: Thank you, that will be quite useful. When do you plan to release such version? I try to make as few user's option as possible, so as to specify 1 thread number for all the other tools in the pipeline. Decreasing the thread number for fastp also imply decreasing it for the other tools, not so fast as fastp, thus affecting the overall performance of the pipeline. Tain.
author: OpenGene

sentence: I just encountered this same issue. Ideally, `fastp` should simply adjust the number of threads accordingly, if necessary, and emit a warning documenting what occurred. It is additionally crucial, in cluster/HPC environments that the number of total threads always be at most the number specified, and ideally be exactly that number for as much of the pipeline as possible.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Excellent! I look forward to seeing this feature implemented. Let me know if you need a beta tester. It'd be awesome if it could stream: read from a pipe, and write to a pipe. sentence: You can use `--length_limit ` option to filter out the reads longer than it after filtering.
author: OpenGene

sentence: You can use `--length_limit ` option to filter out the reads longer than it after filtering.
author: OpenGene

sentence: It was brought to my attention that some small RNA data may pass that filter that didn't have the adapter on it and this is a request on his behalf. I originally suggested the length limit option to him, but he was adamant it wouldn't work because of that and I'm still unclear as to why, but wouldn't accept it as a reasonable method. It's definitely an edge case, but I thought I'd ask in case it was simple. Definitely not a major issue if it doesn't seem reasonable to add when we have the length limit option and I can try re-explaining it to him. Thanks!

I originally suggested the length limit option to him, but he was adamant it wouldn't work because of that and I'm still unclear as to why, but wouldn't accept it as a reasonable method. It's definitely an edge case, but I thought I'd ask in case it was simple. Definitely not a major issue if it doesn't seem reasonable to add when we have the length limit option and I can try re-explaining it to him. Thanks!
author: OpenGene

sentence: I have two questions:. why you do not correct the overlap reads if their mismatch is bigger than 5? Your paper said it can reduce the false correction, but it didn't show any data to support these words. Your overlapanalysis program consider two conditions: (mismatch <5) or (mismatch >=5 and compare match region >50). I was very confused about you didn't correct the overlap reads if its (mismatch >=5 and compare match region > 50). ---- if too many mismatches exist, the confidence of the pair is really overlapped will be low. So then fastp will stop to correct them. can we correct the base if one is in bad quality, the other may be not very good but much better than the bad one, such as bigger than 5? ----No. It may cause over-correction. But probably set them as N is a better idea.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Would you guys prefer write unpaired reads to two files separately, or just write them into one single file?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Yes, two separate files is preferable.
author: OpenGene

sentence: s both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If one read passes the filters but its pair doesn't, the `failure reason` will be `paired_read_is_failing`.
author: OpenGene

sentence: This feature is implemented in fastp v0.19.9 (will be released soon). # input and output. `fastp` supports both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. sentence: This feature is implemented in fastp v0.19.9 (will be released soon). # input and output. `fastp` supports both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If
author: OpenGene

sentence: s both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If one read passes the filters but its pair doesn't, the `failure reason` will be `paired_read_is_failing`.

sentence: This feature is implemented in fastp v0.19.9 (will be released soon). # input and output. `fastp` supports both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If
author: OpenGene

sentence: ts both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If one read passes the filters but its pair doesn't, the `failure reason` will be `paired_read_is_failing`

sentence: s both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If one read passes the filters but its pair doesn't, the `failure reason` will be `paired_read_is_failing`.
author: OpenGene

sentence: This feature is implemented in fastp v0.19.9 (will be released soon). # input and output. `fastp` supports both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If
author: OpenGene

sentence: s both single-end (SE) and paired-end (PE) input/output. * for SE data, you only have to specify read1 input by `-i` or `--in1`, and specify read1 output by `-o` or `--out1`. * for PE data, you should also specify read2 input by `-I` or `--in2`, and specify read2 output by `-O` or `--out2`. * if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. * the output will be gzip-compressed if its file name ends with `.gz`. ## output to STDOUT. `fastp` supports streaming the passing-filter reads to STDOUT, so that it can be passed to other compressors like `bzip2`, or be passed to aligners like `bwa` and `bowtie2`. . * specify `--stdout` to enable this mode to stream output to STDOUT. * for PE data, the output will be interleaved FASTQ, which means the output will contain records like `record1-R1 -> record1-R2 -> record2-R1 -> record2-R2 -> record3-R1 -> record3-R2 ... ` . ## input from STDIN. * specify `--stdin` if you want to read the STDIN for processing. * if the STDIN is an interleaved paired-end stream, specify `--interleaved_in` to indicate that. ## store the unpaired reads for PE data. * you can specify `--unpaired1` to store the reads that read1 passes filters but its paired read2 doesn't, as well as `--unpaired2` for unpaired read2. * `--unpaired1` and `--unpaired2` can be the same, so the unpaired read1/read2 will be written to the same single file. ## store the reads that fail the filters. * give `--failed_out` to specify the file name to store the failed reads. * if one read failed and is written to `--failed_out`, its `failure reason` will be appended to its read name. For example, `failed_quality_filter`, `failed_too_short` etc. * for PE data, if unpaired reads are not stored (by giving --unpaired1 or --unpaired2), the failed pair of reads will be put together. If one read passes the filters but its pair doesn't, the `failure reason` will be `paired_read_is_failing`.

sentence: Sorry, I think my explanation was a bit poor. Let me try again, if you still think it's too specific I understand. In single cell RNA-seq experiments it is very common to have paired-end sequencing. The first read contains **only** barcodes, in the case of 10x Genomics kits (which are very common as well) it 1 barcode for the cell (16 bp) and 1 barcode for each transcript (10 bp), resulting in a total of 26 bp. It would be silly to apply filtering and trimming to this read because these sequences are artificial and always have to be the same length. Instead, the second read comes from the actual transcript, therefore it makes sense to apply filtering and trimming for quality control. At our institute, we use a Illumina NovaSeq sequencer, I would say it's a fairly common machine. I receive two FASTQ files, one containing all read 1, and the other containing all read 2, of course inside the corresponding pairs are in the same order. As described above, if I run fastp on both FASTQ files I run into problems because barcodes are filtered or trimmed. Instead, if I submit only the FASTQ file of the read 2 (from the transcript), the output FASTQ will have fewer reads than read 1 (because it wasn't filtered). This will cause problems later on because the paired FASTQ files are expected to be in sync. When I say 'in sync', I mean that the read pairs are in the same order in their respective FASTQ file, and that only pairs are present. That means, if a read was removed from the R2 FASTQ file, the corresponding read in the R1 FASTQ must be removed as well. Otherwise, you'll end up having different number of reads in the FASTQ files. So I was wondering, since your tool is already able to process paired-end FASTQ files and keep them in sync, if it was possible to use both FASTQ files as input for fastp, but then apply the filtering only to the reads of one of the two files (in this case read 2) and just keep the other one in sync. Technically, I assume this shouldn't be a big ch
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: ng and trimming for quality control. At our institute, we use a Illumina NovaSeq sequencer, I would say it's a fairly common machine. I receive two FASTQ files, one containing all read 1, and the other containing all read 2, of course inside the corresponding pairs are in the same order. As described above, if I run fastp on both FASTQ files I run into problems because barcodes are filtered or trimmed. Instead, if I submit only the FASTQ file of the read 2 (from the transcript), the output FASTQ will have fewer reads than read 1 (because it wasn't filtered). This will cause problems later on because the paired FASTQ files are expected to be in sync. When I say 'in sync', I mean that the read pairs are in the same order in their respective FASTQ file, and that only pairs are present. That means, if a read was removed from the R2 FASTQ file, the corresponding read in the R1 FASTQ must be removed as well. Otherwise, you'll end up having different number of reads in the FASTQ files. So I was wondering, since your tool is already able to process paired-end FASTQ files and keep them in sync, if it was possible to use both FASTQ files as input for fastp, but then apply the filtering only to the reads of one of the two files (in this case read 2) and just keep the other one in sync. Technically, I assume this shouldn't be a big challenge. I would like to look at this myself but I'm not very familiar with C++ and don't have spare time at the moment. After running fastp only on read 2 (in single-end mode), I tried to 'sync' the files manually myself but wasn't able to make it work. Anyway, sorry for the wall of text but I hope this better explains the situations.As I said, I think it shouldn't be too challenging and in my opinion a lot of people could benefit from this (also because single cell RNA-seq experiments are becoming more and more standard and almost always require paired-end sequencing, often having one of the reads containing just barcodes). Thanks for your time
author: OpenGene

When I say 'in sync', I mean that the read pairs are in the same order in their respective FASTQ file, and that only pairs are present. That means, if a read was removed from the R2 FASTQ file, the corresponding read in the R1 FASTQ must be removed as well. Otherwise, you'll end up having different number of reads in the FASTQ files. So I was wondering, since your tool is already able to process paired-end FASTQ files and keep them in sync, if it was possible to use both FASTQ files as input for fastp, but then apply the filtering only to the reads of one of the two files (in this case read 2) and just keep the other one in sync. Technically, I assume this shouldn't be a big ch

sentence: ng and trimming for quality control. At our institute, we use a Illumina NovaSeq sequencer, I would say it's a fairly common machine. I receive two FASTQ files, one containing all read 1, and the other containing all read 2, of course inside the corresponding pairs are in the same order. As described above, if I run fastp on both FASTQ files I run into problems because barcodes are filtered or trimmed. Instead, if I submit only the FASTQ file of the read 2 (from the transcript), the output FASTQ will have fewer reads than read 1 (because it wasn't filtered). This will cause problems later on because the paired FASTQ files are expected to be in sync. When I say 'in sync', I mean that the read pairs are in the same order in their respective FASTQ file, and that only pairs are present. That means, if a read was removed from the R2 FASTQ file, the corresponding read in the R1 FASTQ must be removed as well. Otherwise, you'll end up having different number of reads in the FASTQ files. So I was wondering, since your tool is already able to process paired-end FASTQ files and keep them in sync, if it was possible to use both FASTQ files as input for fastp, but then apply the filtering only to the reads of one of the two files (in this case read 2) and just keep the other one in sync. Technically, I assume this shouldn't be a big challenge. I would like to look at this myself but I'm not very familiar with C++ and don't have spare time at the moment. After running fastp only on read 2 (in single-end mode), I tried to 'sync' the files manually myself but wasn't able to make it work. Anyway, sorry for the wall of text but I hope this better explains the situations.As I said, I think it shouldn't be too challenging and in my opinion a lot of people could benefit from this (also because single cell RNA-seq experiments are becoming more and more standard and almost always require paired-end sequencing, often having one of the reads containing just barcodes). Thanks for your time

author: OpenGene

sentence: Hi there,. I've had the same use case spring up where I've only wanted to trim + filter based on a single biological read, and not associated barcode, umi, etc reads. For anyone interested, I found a pretty easy work around using [fastq-pair](https://github.com/linsalrob/fastq-pair). Assume we have `r1.fq` and `r2.fq`. We want to filter both `r1` and `r2` based on reads in `r1`:. * Run `fastp` on `r1.fq` to filter as you desire. Output to `fastp_r1.fastq`. * Match passing reads in `fastp_r1.fastq` with reads in `r2.fq` using `fastq-pair`. . Hope this helps!

sentence: Your templates are too long. For PE150 data, if your template is longer than 270, it will not be able to be detected as overlapped since 30 bases overlapping is required.
author: OpenGene

sentence: A bash script with a for loop does the trick. Here is an example:. ```. #!/bin/bash. for f1 in *_1_sequence.fq.gz. do. f2=${f1%%_1_sequence.txt.gz}"_2_sequence.fq.gz". fastp -i $f1 -I $f2 -o "trimmed-$f1" -O "trimmed-$f2". done. ```. This outputs two files with the trimmed- tag on each. It assumes that fastp is in your $PATH. You can run it using `source script.sh` from the command line.
author: OpenGene

sentence: A bash script with a for loop does the trick. Here is an example:. ```. #!/bin/bash. for f1 in *_1_sequence.fq.gz. do. f2=${f1%%_1_sequence.txt.gz}"_2_sequence.fq.gz". fastp -i $f1 -I $f2 -o "trimmed-$f1" -O "trimmed-$f2". done. ```. This outputs two files with the trimmed- tag on each. It assumes that fastp is in your $PATH. You can run it using `source script.sh` from the command line.

sentence: Due to multi-threading fastp doesn't keep the order of reads, so it will cause different MD5. But don't worry, it has 0 effect for the downstream analysis since no software relies on the order of reads. If you still have concern, you can specify `-w 1` to use only one thread.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Ah, ok, that explains it. After fastp, we run bwa, and according to https://www.biostars.org/p/238628/ bwa does have randomness that can result in different results from different input read orders. We may end up running fastp single-threaded; we're figuring out the extent of the impact and performance trade offs. Thank you for your help!
author: OpenGene

sentence: I noticed a similar issue when I had fastq files where the sorting was out of order. This happens e. g. when fastq are created from a bam file that is not sorted by read name. See e. g. the `samtools fastq` documentation.

sentence: @sfchen - this means that omitting `--out1` and `--out2` is some kind of **"dry mode"**? So the plots and stats in the "After filtering" sections show how the fastq **would** look like after applying the "real trimming/filtering" by supplying the output file parameters? That would be cool indeed :-)

sentence: The saving of records in the correct orientation is a nice-to-have. My primary concern is demultiplexing by barcode pairs (I guess reverse complimenting the barcode pairs would be computationally less expensive than reverse complimenting the sequence in the case where you are not going to save the reverse complimented sequence upon a match). What I could do for now is save to two files per sample. Sample1_original and Samole1_revcomp for example. I can generate barcode text files up front one with original barcodes, one with revcomp barcodes. E.g. Sample1 AGT TCT. Sample1_revcomp AGA ACT. Would this tool only write record to Sample1.fastq file if it matched AGT (at the beginning of sequence) And TCT (at the end of sequence). And likewise, would this tool only write record to Sample1_revcomp.fastq file if it matched AGA (at the beginning of sequence) And ACT (at the end of sequence). I don't understand the format of barcode text file with regards to enzyme. It is not applicable to me. Do I insert 'Nan' in between those two barcodes?
author: OpenGene

sentence: In this case all the read names were mismatched, I think that in a situation like this it should really raise an error. I don't think it should stop the execution as sometimes read names can be mismatched for other reasons depending on the format, for example downloading from SRA depending on the options can add a .1 and a .2 on the read names. Thanks again!

sentence: In this case all the read names were mismatched, I think that in a situation like this it should really raise an error. I don't think it should stop the execution as sometimes read names can be mismatched for other reasons depending on the format, for example downloading from SRA depending on the options can add a .1 and a .2 on the read names. Thanks again!
author: OpenGene

sentence: I got the same issue when use fastp on ONT data. Really love fastp as it is currently the fastest qc tools I could find, but it would perfect if the limit on trim.front1 could be discarded because we usually need to trim (discard) more than 30 in the front and 100 in the tail in long-read sequencing data. With these changes, people working with long-read data would definitely love it.
author: OpenGene
